BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Old wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The older wind slabs can still be released in some cases especially on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above approximately 2400 m. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes. Avalanches can reach medium size in isolated cases.
As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist loose snow avalanches being released will increase in particular on steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on near-ridge shady slopes at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted.

Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is wet.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will facilitate a gradual change towards better conditions.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding avalanches are the main danger. Wind slabs are in individual cases still prone to triggering in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
An appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes in all aspects in particular below approximately 2600 m. They can be released at any time of day or night. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.

The wind slabs of the last few days are in individual cases still prone to triggering on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2800 m. Avalanches can be released, in particular by large loads and reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations are rare and are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised as well in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.

On extremely steep sunny slopes more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable. Wind slabs are in individual cases still prone to triggering on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2800 m.
The snowpack is wet and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. This applies in particular below approximately 2000 m, as well as on steep sunny slopes. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to rapid softening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Gliding snow represents the main danger.
Wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The hard wind slabs are easy to recognise and can be released in isolated cases especially at their margins, in particular on extremely steep slopes in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. At transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater.
Until the temperature drops only isolated moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses, in particular in steep rocky terrain, and on very steep grassy slopes, caution is to be exercised on very steep south and southwest facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Above approximately 2300 m a lot of snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
More recent wind slabs are to be found also areas not adjacent to ridgelines. As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface.
The snowpack is largely stable and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2900 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The conditions are sometimes critical for backcountry touring and other off-piste activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released easily or naturally, especially above the tree line. The avalanches can especially at their margins be released, even by a single winter sport participant. Avalanches can also penetrate deep layers.
Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather will be very mild. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.
The weather conditions will bring about a slow stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to gradual moistening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes.
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack can indicate the danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry and freeriding conditions are mostly favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are easy to recognise and can be released by large loads at their margins in particular.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs represent the main danger. Avalanches can in isolated cases be released by small loads and reach medium size. This applies in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to consolidation of the snowpack at low and intermediate altitudes. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The older wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2000 m. On steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain small and medium-sized slab avalanches are possible.
Several small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are easy to recognise and unlikely to be released now.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Hardly any snow is lying above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution, especially along the border with France.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, at elevated altitudes. The avalanche prone locations are rather rare. These avalanche prone locations are to be found at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack above approximately 2400 m.
In some places wind slabs are lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 2400 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. At higher altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released easily or naturally, especially in areas close to the tree line. Avalanches can especially at their margins be released, even by a single winter sport participant.
Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather will be very mild. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.
The weather conditions will bring about a slow stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to gradual moistening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2000 m.
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack can indicate the danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In all aspects hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In these regions from a snow sport perspective, insufficient snow is lying.
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects as well as at a distance from ridgelines: The strong wind has transported the fresh and old snow significantly.
Especially transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind: The hard wind slabs can be released in isolated cases at their margins, especially on extremely steep slopes at high altitude.
Until the temperature drops only isolated moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they will be mostly small. This applies in particular in steep rocky terrain, and at the base of rock walls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular on sunny slopes a little snow is lying in all altitude zones. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface.
The snowpack is largely stable and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2900 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche conditions are generally favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The somewhat older wind slabs are easy to recognise and unlikely to be released now. Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines. Mostly avalanches are rather small.

On very steep sunny slopes individual mostly small loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack will be quite stable. The wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes.

Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is wet and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases, this also applies on steep sunny slopes at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A quite favourable avalanche situation will be encountered over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all aspects hardly any snow is lying.
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The conditions are generally favourable. Gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, especially on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation wet loose snow avalanches are possible as the day progresses.

The somewhat older wind slabs are in individual cases still prone to triggering on very steep shady slopes in high Alpine regions, in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. They can be released, mostly by large loads. The avalanche prone locations are very rare and are easy to recognise. Avalanches can in very isolated cases penetrate deep layers.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs of the last few days are lying on soft layers on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted.
Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes.

Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is wet and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases, this also applies on steep sunny slopes at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The conditions are generally favourable. Gliding avalanches require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Hardly any small avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming. Very isolated avalanche prone locations are to be found at high altitude and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The more recent wind slabs are to be found in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. They are very small. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to softening of the old snowpack. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint. There is a danger of falling on the icy crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be well bonded at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a strong melt-freeze crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche conditions are generally favourable. Old wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise but can be released in isolated cases. Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above approximately 2400 m. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist loose snow avalanches being released will increase in particular on steep sunny slopes. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be quite stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.
